Day after day, alone on a hill

Paul respects the solitude:

It was this idea of a fool on the hill, a guru in a cave, I was attracted to. I remember once hearing about a hermit who missed the Second World War because he’d been in a cave in Italy, and that always appealed to me.
A simple truth – people do not like what they do not understand; this fits perfectly with the statement in the previous line.

This song is not only about a contemplative genius, but it’s also about the idea that what is accepted by most is assumed to be the “actually correct” idea. But someone with actual genius understands and rejects that model, knowing that fad isn’t always fact.

But the fool on the hill sees the sun going down
 And the eyes in his head see the world spinning around

“The Fool On The Hill” was Paul McCartney’s major contribution to the Magical Mystery Tour album. In the companion TV film, it appeared over a sequence shot on a hilltop near Nice in France.

Now that’s Paul. Another good lyric. Shows he’s capable of writing complete songs.

–John Lennon



The song was composed on the piano at McCartney’s father’s house in Liverpool, “hitting a D 6th chord.”

The Fool On The Hill was mine and I think I was writing about someone like Maharishi. His detractors called him a fool. Because of his giggle he wasn’t taken too seriously. It was this idea of a fool on the hill, a guru in a cave, I was attracted to.

–Paul McCartney

But the fool on the hill sees the sun going down
 And the eyes in his head see the world spinning around

McCartney:

Saviours or gurus are generally spat upon, so I thought for my generation I’d suggest that they weren’t as stupid as they looked.

The “fool” sees the sun going down, but he figures out that the sun is not really going anywhere. He comes to understand (“the eyes in his head see”) that the sun is still and the earth is turning.

This song is about the contemplative geniuses who see the world as it really is, and how others react to them.
The man with the foolish grin is keeping perfectly still

McCartney explained:

I think I was writing about someone like Maharishi. His detractors called him a fool. Because of his giggle he wasn’t taken too seriously. […] There were some good words in it, ‘perfectly still,’ I liked that.

Rather than a giggle, in this song the “fool” has a silly grin that makes people dismiss him.

Total calmness and facial relaxation (meditating?) is considered “a foolish grin”.
